documentation.result: The shortest path between a list of two objects in a graph computed with GPU

example.equals: A path between ag1 and ag2

documentation.result: The shortest path between a list of two objects in a graph computed with CPU

example.equals: A path between ag1 and ag2

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clustered by EM Algorithm based on the given attributes. Some paremeters can be defined: max_iterations: the maximum number of iterations to perform;num_clusters: the number of clusters; minStdDev: minimum allowable standard deviation

example.equals: for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clustered by Farthest First Algorithm based on the given attributes. Some paremeters can be defined: num_clusters: the number of clusters

example.equals: for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clusteredby CobWeb Algorithm based on the given attributes. Some paremeters can be defined: acuity: minimum standard deviation for numeric attributes; cutoff: category utility threshold by which to prune nodes seed

example.equals: for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clustered by K-Means Algorithm based on the given attributes. Some paremeters can be defined: distance_f: The distance function to use. 4 possible distance functions: euclidean (by default) ; 'chebyshev', 'manhattan' or 'levenshtein'; dont_replace_missing_values: if false, replace missing values globally with mean/mode; max_iterations: the maximum number of iterations to perform;num_clusters: the number of clusters

example.equals: for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clustered by X-Means Algorithm based on the given attributes. Some paremeters can be defined: bin_value: value given for true value of boolean attributes; cut_off_factor: the cut-off factor to use;distance_f: The distance function to use. 4 possible distance functions: euclidean (by default) ; 'chebyshev', 'manhattan' or 'levenshtein'; max_iterations: the maximum number of iterations to perform; max_kmeans: the maximum number of iterations to perform in KMeans; max_kmeans_for_children: the maximum number of iterations KMeans that is performed on the child centers;max_num_clusters: the maximum number of clusters; min_num_clusters: the minimal number of clusters

example.equals: for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clustered by DBScan Algorithm based on the given attributes. Some paremeters can be defined: distance_f: The distance function to use for instances comparison (euclidean or manhattan); min_points: minimun number of DataObjects required in an epsilon-range-queryepsilon: epsilon -- radius of the epsilon-range-queries

example.equals: for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: Inverse Distance Weighting (IDW) is a type of deterministic method for multivariate interpolation with a known scattered set of points. The assigned values to each geometry are calculated with a weighted average of the values available at the known points. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_distance_weighting Usage: IDW (list of geometries, map of points (key: point, value: value), power parameter)

example.equals: for example, can return [ag1::12.0, ag2::23.0,ag3::12.0,ag4::14.0,ag5::17.0]

usage.descUsageElt: returns the geometry corresponding to the transfomartion of the given geometry by the current CRS (Coordinate Reference System), the one corresponding to the world's agent one

example.equals: a geometry corresponding to the agent geometry transformed into the current CRS

usage.descUsageElt: returns the geometry corresponding to the transfomartion of the given geometry by the left operand CRS (Coordinate Reference System)

example.equals: a geometry corresponding to the agent geometry transformed into the EPSG:4326 CRS

usage.descUsageElt: returns the geometry corresponding to the transfomartion of the given geometry to the GAMA CRS (Coordinate Reference System) assuming the given geometry is referenced by the current CRS, the one corresponding to the world's agent one

example.equals: a geometry corresponding to the agent geometry transformed into the GAMA CRS

usage.descUsageElt: returns the geometry corresponding to the transfomartion of the given geometry to the GAMA CRS (Coordinate Reference System) assuming the given geometry is referenced by given CRS

example.equals: a geometry corresponding to the agent geometry transformed into the GAMA CRS

documentation.result: fuzzy kappa simulation indicator for 2 map comparisons: fuzzy_kappa_sim(agents_list,list_vals1,list_vals2, output_similarity_per_agents,fuzzy_transitions_matrix, fuzzy_distance). Reference: Jasper van Vliet, Alex Hagen-Zanker, Jelle Hurkens, Hedwig van Delden, A fuzzy set approach to assess the predictive accuracy of land use simulations, Ecological Modelling, 24 July 2013, Pages 32-42, ISSN 0304-3800, fuzzy kappa simulation indicator for 2 map comparisons: fuzzy_kappa_sim(agents_list,list_vals1,list_vals2, output_similarity_per_agents,fuzzy_transitions_matrix, fuzzy_distance, weights). Reference: Jasper van Vliet, Alex Hagen-Zanker, Jelle Hurkens, Hedwig van Delden, A fuzzy set approach to assess the predictive accuracy of land use simulations, Ecological Modelling, 24 July 2013, Pages 32-42, ISSN 0304-3800,

kappa indicator for 2 map comparisons: kappa(list_vals1,list_vals2,categories). Reference: Cohen, J. A coefficient of agreement for nominal scales. Educ. Psychol. Meas. 1960, 20.kappa indicator for 2 map comparisons: kappa(list_vals1,list_vals2,categories, weights). Reference: Cohen, J. A coefficient of agreement for nominal scales. Educ. Psychol. Meas. 1960, 20.

The map comparison kit, Environmental Modelling & Software, 21fuzzy kappa indicator for 2 map comparisons: fuzzy_kappa(agents_list,list_vals1,list_vals2, output_similarity_per_agents,categories,fuzzy_categories_matrix, fuzzy_distance). usage.descUsageElt: if the left operand is a polyline and the right operand a float for the area, returrns the y coordinate of the water (water level)
if the left operand is a polyline and the right operand a float for the water y coordinate, returrns the shapes of the river sections (list of list of points)
if the left operand is a polyline and the right operand a float for the water y coordinate, returrns the area of the water (water flow area)

documentation.result: Tests whether the operand is a obj file.
Constructs a file of type obj. Allowed extensions are limited to obj
Tests whether the operand is a threeds file.
Constructs a file of type threeds. Allowed extensions are limited to 3ds, max
WMS: A simple call to WMS
REST: Read data from RESTService
WMS: A simple call to WFS/GML2
WMS: A simple call to WMS
creates a graph from the list/map of edges given as operand and connect the node to the edge

example.code: as_driving_graph(road,node) --: build a graph while using the road agents as edges and the node agents as nodes

documentation.result: Returns the phi-quantile; that is, an element elem for which holds that phi percent of data elements are less than elem. The quantile need not necessarily be contained in the data sequence, it can be a linear interpolation.
Returns the sum of the terms 0 through k of the Binomial probability density, where n is the number of trials and p is the probability of success in the range 0 to 1.

Returns the linearly interpolated number of elements in a list less or equal to a given element. The rank is the number of elements <= element. Ranks are of the form {0, 1, 2,..., sortedList.size()}. If no element is <= element, then the rank is zero. If the element lies in between two contained elements, then linear interpolation is used and a non integer value is returned.
Returns the area under the left hand tail (from 0 to x) of the Chi square probability density function with df degrees of freedom.
Durbin-Watson computation
Returns the complemented regularized incomplete Gamma function of the argument a and integration start point x.
Returns the regularized integral of the Gamma function with argument a to the integration end point x.
Returns the correlation of two data sequences
Returns the auto-correlation of a data sequence
Returns how many percent of the elements contained in the receiver are <= element. Does linear interpolation if the element is not contained but lies in between two contained elements.
Returns the integral from zero to x of the gamma probability density function.
documentation.comment: incomplete_gamma(a,x) is equal to pgamma(a,1,x).

documentation.result: Returns the moment of k-th order with constant c of a data sequence

Returns the RMS (Root-Mean-Square) of a data sequence. The RMS of data sequence is the square-root of the mean of the squares of the elements in the data sequence. It is a measure of the average size of the elements of a data sequence.
Returns the log of the value of the Gamma function at x.
Returns the area to the left of x in the Student T distribution with the given degrees of freedom.
Returns the probability of x in the normal distribution with the given mean and standard deviation.
Returns the covariance of two data sequences
Returns the value, t, for which the area under the Student-t probability density function (integrated from minus infinity to t) is equal to x.
Returns the beta function with arguments a, b.
Returns the regularized integral of the beta function with arguments a and b, from zero to x.
Returns the skew of a data sequence.Returns the skew of a data sequence, which is moment(data,3,mean) / standardDeviation3
Returns the value of the Gamma function at x.
Returns the variance of a data sequence. That is (sumOfSquares - mean*sum) / size with mean = sum/size.Returns the variance from a standard deviation.
Returns the area under the right hand tail (from x to infinity) of the Chi square probability density function with df degrees of freedom.

Returns the x in the normal distribution with the given mean and standard deviation, to the left of which lies the given area. normal.Inverse returns the value in terms of standard deviations from the mean, so we need to adjust it for the given mean and standard deviation.
Returns the integral from x to infinity of the gamma probability density function.
Returns the kurtosis (aka excess) of a data sequenceReturns the kurtosis (aka excess) of a data sequence
Returns the sum of the terms k+1 through n of the Binomial probability density, where n is the number of trials and P is the probability of success in the range 0 to 1.
Returns the P value of F statistic fstat with numerator degrees of freedom dfn and denominator degress of freedom dfd. Uses the incomplete Beta function.
Returns the area to the left of x in the normal distribution with the given mean and standard deviation.
Returns the P value of the T statistic tstat with df degrees of freedom. This is a two-tailed test so we just double the right tail which is given by studentT of -|tstat|.
Returns n choose k as a double. Note the integerization of the double return value.
A list of geometries (hexagonal) corresponding to the hexagonal tesselation of the first operand geometry

example.equals: list of geometries (hexagonal) corresponding to the hexagonal tesselation of the first operand geometry

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) partially overlaps the right-geometry (or agent/point).
documentation.comment: if one geometry operand fully covers the other geometry operand, returns false (contrarily to the overlaps operator).

usage.descUsageElt: if one of the operand is null, returns false.

documentation.result: A matrix of square geometries (grid with 8-neighbourhood) with dimension given by the rigth-hand operand ({nb_cols, nb_lines}) corresponding to the square tessellation of the left-hand operand geometry (geometry, agent)

example.equals: a matrix of square geometries (grid with 8-neighbourhood) with 10 columns and 5 lines corresponding to the square tessellation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A triangle geometry which side size is given by the operand.
documentation.comment: the centre of the triangle is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

example.equals: a geometry as a triangle with side_size = 5.

usage.descUsageElt: returns nil if the operand is nil.

documentation.result: A mix of square and circle geometry (see : http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squircle), which side size is equal to the first operand and power is equal to the second operand
documentation.comment: the centre of the ellipse is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

example.equals: a geometry as a squircle of side 4 with a power of 4.

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the side operand is lower or equal to 0.

documentation.result: An agent among the left-operand list of agents, species or meta-population (addition of species), the closest to the operand (casted as a geometry).
documentation.comment: the distance is computed in the topology of the calling agent (the agent in which this operator is used), with the distance algorithm specific to the topology.

example.equals: return the closest agent among ag1, ag2 and ag3 to the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A geometry collection (multi-geometry) composed of the given list of geometries.

example.equals: a geometry composed of the 4 points (multi-point).

usage.descUsageElt: if the operand is nil, returns the point geometry {0,0}
if the operand is composed of a single geometry, returns a copy of the geometry.

documentation.result: A geometry corresponding to the cleaning of the operand (geometry, agent, point)
documentation.comment: The cleaning corresponds to a buffer with a distance of 0.0

example.equals: returns the geometry resulting from the cleaning of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A path between a list of two geometries (geometries, agents or points) considering a topology.

example.equals: A path between ag1 and ag2

documentation.result: A list of agents among the left-operand list, species or meta-population (addition of species), overlapping the operand (casted as a geometry).

example.equals: return the agents among ag1, ag2 and ag3 that overlap the shape of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A geometry corresponding to the operand geometry (geometry, agent, point) without its holes

example.equals: the geometry corresponding to the geometry of the agent applying the operator without its holes.

documentation.result: A point inside (or touching) the operand-geometry.

example.equals: a point in the square, for example : {3,4.6}.

documentation.result: A tree (list of list) contained groups of agents clustered by distance considering a distance min between two groups.
documentation.comment: use of hierarchical clustering with Minimum for linkage criterion between two groups of agents.

example.equals: for example, can return [[[ag1],[ag3]], [ag2], [[[ag4],[ag5]],[ag6]]

documentation.result: The direction (in degree) between the two geometries (geometries, agents, points) considering the topology of the agent applying the operator.

example.equals: the direction between ag1 and ag2 and ag3 considering the topology of the agent applying the operator

documentation.result: An agent, the closest to the operand (casted as a geometry).
documentation.comment: the distance is computed in the topology of the calling agent (the agent in which this operator is used), with the distance algorithm specific to the topology.

example.equals: the closest agent to the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A polyhedron geometry from the given list of points.

example.equals: a polygon geometry composed of the 4 points and of depth 10.

usage.descUsageElt: if the operand is nil, returns the point geometry {0,0}
if the operand is composed of a single point, returns a point geometry
if the operand is composed of 2 points, returns a polyline geometry.

usage.descUsageElt: if one of the operand is null, returns false.

The assigned values to each geometry are calculated with a weighted average of the values available at the known points. usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.

a circle geometry of radius 10, displayed as a sphere with 2 slices.

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.
returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.

if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a float, returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) scaled by the right-hand operand coefficient

if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a point, returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) scaled by the right-hand operand coefficients in the 3 dimensions

documentation.result: A list of agents covered by the operand (casted as a geometry).

example.equals: the agents that are covered by the shape of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A 3D geometry that represents the box that surrounds the geometries or the surface described by the arguments. More general than geometry(arguments).envelope, as it allows to pass int, double, point, image files, shape files, asc files, or any list combining these arguments, in which case the envelope will be correctly expanded. If an envelope cannot be determined from the arguments, a default one of dimensions (0,100, 0, 100, 0, 100) is returned
A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) overlaps the right-geometry (or agent/point).

usage.descUsageElt: if one of the operand is null, returns false.
if one operand is a point, returns true if the point is included in the geometry

documentation.result: The two part of the left-operand lines split at the given right-operand point

usage.descUsageElt: if the left-operand is a point or a polygon, returns an empty list

documentation.result: A list of agents among the left-operand list that are located at a distance <= the right operand from the caller agent (in its topology)

example.equals: the agents of the list located at a distance <= 20 from the caller agent (in the same order).

documentation.result: A circle geometry which radius is equal to the operand.
documentation.comment: the centre of the circle is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

example.equals: a geometry as a circle of radius 10.

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.
if the right-operand is a list of points, geometries or agents, returns the geometry resulting from the difference between the left-geometry and all of the right-geometries

example.equals: rectangle(10,10) - (circle(2) + square(2))

usage.descUsageElt: if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a float, returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) reduced by the right-hand operand distance

usage.descUsageElt: if both operands are a point, a geometry or an agent, returns the geometry resulting from the difference between both geometries

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) is disjoints from the right-geometry (or agent/point).

usage.descUsageElt: if one of the operand is null, returns true.
if one operand is a point, returns false if the point is included in the geometry.

documentation.result: a list, containing all the agents of the same species than the left argument (if it is an agent) located at a distance inferior or equal to the right-hand operand to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point).
documentation.comment: The topology used to compute the neighbourhood is the one of the left-operand if this one is an agent; otherwise the one of the agent applying the operator.

example.equals: all the agents located at a distance lower or equal to 10 to the agent applying the operator.
a geometry corresponding to union between geom1, geom2 and geom3

usage.descUsageElt: if the right-operand is a container of points, geometries or agents, returns the geometry resulting from the union all the geometries

if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a map (with [distance::float, quadrantSegments:: int (the number of line segments used to represent a quadrant of a circle), endCapStyle::int (1: (default) a semi-circle, 2: a straight line perpendicular to the end segment, 3: a half-square)]), returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) enlarged considering the right-hand operand parameters

documentation.result: A distance between two geometries (geometries, agents or points) considering the topology of the agent applying the operator.

example.equals: the distance between ag1 and ag2 considering the topology of the agent applying the operator

documentation.result: A list of geometries (polylines) corresponding to the skeleton of the operand geometry (geometry, agent)

example.equals: the list of geometries corresponding to the skeleton of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A list of agents among the left-operand list, species or meta-population (addition of species), covered by the operand (casted as a geometry).

example.equals: the agents among ag1, ag2 and ag3 that are covered by the shape of the right-hand argument.
the agents among species species1 and species2 that are covered by the shape of the right-hand argument.

documentation.result: Sets the z ordinate of the n-th point of a geometry to the value provided by the third argument

example.code: loop i from: 0 to: length(shape.points) - 1{set shape <- set_z (shape, i, 3.0);}

documentation.result: A matrix of square geometries (grid with 4-neighbourhood) with dimension given by the rigth-hand operand ({nb_cols, nb_lines}) corresponding to the square tessellation of the left-hand operand geometry (geometry, agent)

example.equals: the matrix of square geometries (grid with 4-neighbourhood) with 10 columns and 5 lines corresponding to the square tessellation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: An pacman geometry with a dynamic opening mouth which radius is equal to first argument.An pacman geometry which radius is equal to first argument.
documentation.comment: the centre of the sphere is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.the centre of the sphere is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

example.equals: a geometry as a circle of radius 10 but displays a sphere.
a geometry as a circle of radius 10 but displays a sphere.

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.
returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the application of a rotation by the right-hand operand angles (degree) along the three axis (x,y,z) to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point)A geometry resulting from the application of a rotation by the right-hand operand angle (degree) to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point)
documentation.comment: the right-hand operand can be a float or a int

example.equals: the geometry resulting from a 45 degres rotation along the {1,0,0} vector to the geometry of the agent applying the operator.
the geometry resulting from a 45 degres rotation to the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the application of a translation by the right-hand operand distance to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point)

example.equals: the geometry resulting from applying the translation to the left-hand geometry (or agent).

documentation.result: A list of geometries (triangles) corresponding to the Delaunay triangulation of the operand geometry (geometry, agent, point)

example.equals: the list of geometries (triangles) corresponding to the Delaunay triangulation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.
the list of geometries (triangles) corresponding to the Delaunay triangulation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A cone geometry which radius is equal to the operand.
documentation.comment: the centre of the cone is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

example.equals: a geometry as a circle of radius 10 but displays a cone.

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.

documentation.result: A triangle geometry which side size is given by the operand.
documentation.comment: the centre of the triangle is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

example.equals: a geometry as a triangle with side_size = 5.

usage.descUsageElt: returns nil if the operand is nil.

documentation.result: An sphere geometry which radius is equal to the operand made of 2 hemisphere.
documentation.comment: the centre of the sphere is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

example.equals: a circle geometry of radius 10, displayed as a slice.

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.

documentation.result: A sphere geometry which radius is equal to the operand made of 2 hemispheres.
documentation.comment: the centre of the sphere is by default the location of the current agent that is calling this operator.

example.equals: a circle geometry of radius 10, displayed as an antislice.

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.

documentation.result: allows to restrict the size of a geometry so that it fits in the envelope {width, height, depth} defined by the second operand

example.equals: a geometry corresponding to the geometry of the agent applying the operator scaled so that it fits a square of 10x10

documentation.result: A list of agents situated at a distance lower than the right argument.

example.equals: all the agents (excluding the caller) which distance to the caller is lower than 20

documentation.result: A distance between a list of geometries (geometries, agents, points) considering a topology.

example.equals: the distance between ag1, ag2 and ag3 considering the topology my_topology

documentation.result: A direction (in degree) between a list of two geometries (geometries, agents, points) considering a topology.

example.equals: the direction between ag1 and ag2 considering the topology my_topology

documentation.result: A list of left-operand number of points located at a the right-operand distance to the agent location.

example.equals: returns [pt1, pt2, pt3] with pt1, pt2 and pt3 located at a distance of 20.0 to the agent location

documentation.result: An arc, which radius is equal to the first operand, heading to the second, amplitude to the third and a boolean indicating whether to return a linestring or a polygon to the fourthAn arc, which radius is equal to the first operand, heading to the second and amplitude the third
documentation.comment: the centre of the arc is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.the centre of the arc is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator. This operator returns a polygon by default.

example.equals: a geometry as an arc of radius 4, in a direction of 45 and an amplitude of 90, which only contains the points on the arc
a geometry as an arc of radius 4, in a direction of 45 and an amplitude of 90

usage.descUsageElt: returns a point if the radius operand is lower or equal to 0.
returns a point if the radius operand is lower or equal to 0.

the specified intention is put on hold (fited plan are not considered) until specific condition is reached. Can be an expression (which will be tested), a list (of subintentions), or nil (by default the condition will be the current list of subintentions of the intention)
puts the current intention on hold until the specified condition is reached or all subintentions are reached (not in desire base anymore).

Connection parameters
SQL commands such as Create, Update, Delete, Drop with question mark
List of values that are used to replace question mark
Table name
List of column name of table
List of values that are used to insert into table. Columns and values must have same size
select string
List of values that are used to replace question marks
Connection parameters
Connection parameters
the graph to apply the layout.
The number of steps of the algorithm to perform (default 1).
More threads means more speed (default: 1).
Distributes attraction along outbound edges. Hubs attract less and thus are pushed to the borders (default: false).
Switch model from lin-lin to lin-log. Makes clusters more tight (default: false).
Should not be used with approximate_repulsion default: false
How much influence you give to the edges wight. 0 is no influence, 1 is normal. default: 1.0
How much repulsion you want. More makes a more sparse graph. default: 2.0
A stronger gravity law default: false
Attracts nodes to the center. Prevents islands from drifting away. default: 1.0
How much swinging you allow. Above 1 discouraged. Lower gives less speed and more precision. default: 0.1
Barnes Hut optimization: n2 complexity to n.ln(n); allows larger graphs. default: false
Theta of the Barnes Hut optimization. default: 1.2
The new nodes positions are bounded within the two bound points if both are not null. default: null
The new nodes positions are bounded within the two bound points if both are not null. default: null
the graph to apply the layout.
the natural length of the springs. Bigger values mean nodes will be farther apart (default: 100).
The maximum level to be used in the quadtree representation. Greater values mean more accuracy (default: 10).
The theta parameter for Barnes-Hut opening criteria. Smaller values mean more accuracy (default: 1.2).
The relative strength between electrical force (repulsion) and spring force (attriaction). default: 0.2
The step size used in the algorithm. It has to be a meaningful size compared to the optimal distance (e.g. 10%). default: 10
The number of steps of the algorithm to perform (default 1).
The new nodes positions are bounded within the two bound points if both are not null. default: null
The new nodes positions are bounded within the two bound points if both are not null. default: null
The path to music file. This path is relative to the path of the model.
Mode of
the variable to be diffused
the species (in general a grid), on which the diffusion will occur
the diffusion matrix (can have any size)
the diffusion method
a matrix masking the diffusion (matrix created from a image for example)
a diffusion rate
a diffusion radius
the number of diffusion operation applied in one simulation step
This statements allows a value to diffuse among a species on agents (generally on a grid) depending on a given diffusion matrix.

usage.descUsageElt: A basic example of diffusion of the variable phero defined in the species cells, given a diffusion matrix math_diff is:

example.code: diffusion var: phero on: cells mat_diffu: math_diff;

usage.descUsageElt: The diffusion can be masked by obstacles, created from a bitmap image:

example.code: diffusion var: phero on: cells mat_diffu: math_diff mask: mymask;

usage.descUsageElt: A convenient way to have an uniform diffusion in a given radius is (which is equivalent to the above diffusion):

example.code: diffusion var: phero on: cells proportion: 1/9 radius: 1;

documentation.result: the equation system identifier to be numerically solved
integrate method (can be only "rk4" or "dp853") (default value: "rk4")
time interval inside integration process
list of variables's value inside integration process
number of discret beside 2 step of simulation (default value: 0)
initial time
target time for the integration (can be set to a value smaller than t0 for backward integration)
length of simulation cycle which will be synchronize with step of integrator (default value: 1)
integration step, use with most integrator methods (default value: 1)
minimal step, (used with dp853 method only), (sign is irrelevant, regardless of integration direction, forward or backward), the last step can be smaller than this value
maximal step, (used with dp853 method only), (sign is irrelevant, regardless of integration direction, forward or backward), the last step can be smaller than this value
allowed absolute error (used with dp853 method only)
allowed relative error (used with dp853 method only)
Solves all equations which matched the given name, with all systems of agents that should solved simultaneously.
the equation identifier

facet.name: type
facet.values: , takes values in: {SI, SIS, SIR, SIRS, SEIR, LV}

documentation.result: the choice of one among classical models (SI, SIS, SIR, SIRS, SEIR, LV)
the list of variables used in predefined equation systems
the list of pramameters used in predefined equation systems
a list of agents containing a system of equations (all systems will be solved simultaneously)
The equation statement is used to create an equation system from several single equations.

usage.descUsageElt: If the simultaneously: facet is used, system of all the agents will be solved simultaneously.
The basic syntax to define an equation system is:

If the type: facet is used, a predefined equation system is defined using variables vars: and parameters params: in the right order. All possible predefined equation systems are the following ones (see [EquationPresentation161 EquationPresentation161] for precise definition of each classical equation system):

example.code: equation eqSI type: SI vars: [S,I,t] params: [N,beta];
equation eqSIS type: SIS vars: [S,I,t] params: [N,beta,gamma];
equation eqSIRS type: SIRS vars: [S,I,R,t] params: [N,beta,gamma,omega,mu];
equation eqSEIR type: SEIR vars: [S,E,I,R,t] params: [N,beta,gamma,sigma,mu];
equation eqLV type: LV vars: [x,y,t] params: [alpha,beta,delta,gamma] ;

documentation.result: the left part of the equation (it should be a variable or a call to the diff() or diff2() operators)
the right part of the equation (it is mandatory that it can be evaluate to a float
Allows to implement an equation in the form function(n, t) = expression. The left function is only here as a placeholder for enabling a simpler syntax and grabbing the variable as its left member.

usage.descUsageElt: The syntax of the = statement is a bit different from the other statements. It hase to be used as follows (in an equation):

documentation.result: the value that is evaluated and compared to other facets
an expresion, assert tests whether the value is equals to this expression
an expression, assert tests whether the value is not equals to this expression
"error" or "warning", used in testing what raises the evaluation of the value: expresion
Allows to check whether the evaluation of a given expression fulfils a given condition. If it is not fulfilled, an exception is raised.

usage.descUsageElt: if the equals: facet is used, the equality between the evaluation of expressions in the value: and in the equals: facets is tested
if the is_not: facet is used, the inequality between the evaluation of expressions in the value: and in the equals: facets is tested
if the raises: facet is used with either "warning" or "error", the statement tests whether the evaluation of the value: expression raises an error (resp. a warning)

documentation.result: identifier of the test

The test statement allows modeler to define a set of assertions that will be tested. Before the execution of the embeded set of instructions, if a setup is defined in the species, model or experiment, it is executed. In a test, if one assertion fails, the evaluation of other assertions continue (if GAMA is configured in the preferences that the program does not stop at the first exception).

usage.descUsageElt: An example of use:

example.code: // set of attributes that will be used in test

documentation.result: any type of data (it can be geometry, image, text)
the shape to display
the text to draw
path of the icon to draw (JPEG, PNG, GIF)
the texture that should be applied to the geometry
a condition specifying whether the geometry is empty or full
if used with a color, represents the color of the geometry border. If set to false, expresses that no border should be drawn. If not set, the borders will be drawn using the color of the geometry.
specify whether the geometry have to be rounded (e.g. for squares)
location where the shape/text/icon is drawn
size of the text/icon (not used in the context of the drawing of a geometry)
the color to use to display the text/icon/geometry
orientation of the shape/text/icon
orientation of the shape/text/icon
the font used to draw the text

(only if the display type is opengl) Add a depth to the geometry previously defined (a line becomes a plan, a circle becomes a cylinder, a square becomes a cube, a polygon becomes a polyhedron with height equal to the depth value). Note: This only works if a the agent has not a point geometry
the size of the arrow, located at the beginning of the drawn geometry
the size of the arrow, located at the end of the drawn geometry
the style used to display text
`draw` is used in an aspect block to expresse how agents of the species will be drawn. It is evaluated each time the agent has to be drawn. It can also be used in the graphics block.

usage.descUsageElt: Any kind of geometry as any location can be drawn when displaying an agent (independently of his shape)
Image or text can also be drawn

example.code: draw "Current state= "+state at: location + {-3,1.5} color: #white font: font('Default', 12, #bold) ;
draw file(ant_shape_full) rotate: heading at: location size: 5

usage.descUsageElt: Arrows can be drawn with any kind of geometry, using begin_arrow and end_arrow facets, combined with the empty: facet to specify whether it is plain or empty

example.code: draw line([{10, 10},{20, 50}, {40, 70}]) color: #green end_arrow: 2 begin_arrow: 2 empty: true;
draw square(10) at: {80,20} color: #purple begin_arrow: 2 empty: true;
